{"step_by_step_thinking": "According to the relevant documents, the structures that are mentioned as lying deep to the hyoglossus muscle are the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve 9), the stylohyoid ligament, and the lingual artery and lingual vein. The hypoglossal nerve is mentioned as passing through the gap between the superior constrictor, middle constrictor, and mylohyoid muscles to reach the tongue, which indicates that it is not deep to the hyoglossus muscle. The geniohyoid muscle is described as being immediately superior to the mylohyoid muscles in the floor of the mouth, which suggests that it is not deep to the hyoglossus muscle. The stylohyoid muscle is mentioned as passing inferiorly and anteriorly between the internal and external carotid arteries, which indicates that it is not deep to the hyoglossus muscle. Based on this information, the structure that is not mentioned as lying deep to the hyoglossus muscle is the geniohyoid muscle.", "answer_choice": "D"}
